results.content:
Yes, up to expectation, few things that I saw is 
1> Web API security: Directly you copied the code and pasted during the generate token blah blah.. but for us it's really difficult to repeat the same.

2> Versioning Web API:
Setting up in start up class was again a matter.. even clarification was not up to the mark..

response.content:
Thank you Noorulla for your kind feedback. Yes you may have seen I copied the generated token from the Postman in the Web API controller as I am stepping through the code. The generated JWT is unique every time it is generated and you can also explore and review the generated token in the jwt.io portal. I have also included the source code of this course in video 6 of Section 2. And when you generate your own jwt token, make sure to use your localhost port number in your code.
Regarding the versioning, various options are demonstrated including the use of HeaderApiVersionReader which lets you keep your API URL clean and the API version information can be passed via appending an HTTP header which as you can see is configured in the startup.cs class. My apologies if it was not very clear to you. All the very best and thanks once again for your input!

I have also included the source code of this course in video 6 of Section 2. And when you generate your own jwt token, make sure to use your localhost port number in your code.
Regarding the versioning, various options are demonstrated including the use of HeaderApiVersionReader which lets you keep your API URL clean and the API version information can be passed via appending an HTTP header which as you can see is configured in the startup.cs class. My apologies if it was not very clear to you. All the very best and thanks once again for your input!
